Home / Xpress Weigh

Empowering Consultants to support members on their weight-loss journey.

  • Slimming World
  • 2025

A multi-phase redesign of Slimming World's flagship member-support tool, delivered as part of the organisation's wider digital transformation.

Working across the Consultant ecosystem, I led the experience direction for the live member-support tool in collaboration with Product Owners, Business Analysts, engineering and executive stakeholders. This case study focuses on the screens used by Consultants during weekly group sessions.

Role

  • Longitudinal ethnographic research
  • Executive stakeholder alignment
  • Experience strategy & interaction design
  • Moderated usability testing
  • Cross-functional product collaboration

TL;DR

I led the redesign of the Consultant ecosystem within Slimming World’s digital transformation, grounded in long-term ethnographic research.

Xpress Weigh was the first major delivery within the redesigned Consultant ecosystem.

  • Phase 1: Reduced friction in the legacy member support tool — >90% voluntary adoption in six weeks.
  • Phase 2: Challenged and redefined the underlying information model, securing executive alignment on core priorities.
  • Pivot: Adapted the interaction model when group methodology changed, without restarting the work.
  • Validation & risk reduction: Stress-tested the design through immersive usability testing before development.

Phase 1

Problem

‘Xpress Weigh’ was a legacy suite of tools used by Consultants to run weekly member groups. Running on Windows tablets, it supported enrollment, payments, weight recording and access to member data during live sessions.

Over time, technical and design debt had resulted in dense, data-heavy screens. There was little distinction between data needed in the moment and data that was simply available.

Weekly groups are fast-paced and emotionally sensitive. Consultants are often standing, moving between members and maintaining a human connection. In practice, they were navigating the interface while trying to manage the room.

As Slimming World began exploring broader digital transformation, the member-support experience came under scrutiny. The system worked, but it wasn't helping Consultants focus on the conversation in front of them.

I was asked to deliver targeted improvements within legacy constraints, with a focus on reducing friction during live sessions.

Exisiting solution: Two complex screens were a barrier to natural, supportive member conversations.

Approach

Years of embedded ethnographic exposure — participating in groups as both a member and assistant — gave me a grounded understanding of real-world use. Targeted one-to-one interviews with Consultants across experience levels validated and sharpened those insights.

The findings were consistent: live sessions were slowed by hunt-and-peck navigation, most available data went untouched, and workarounds had become normalised.

Collaborating with the Directors of Field and Training, I led the review of the interface through the lens of the live session. We examined each on-screen element and asked whether it actively supported the interaction in the room.

The layout was simplified, prioritising glanceability, single-click input and ergonomics for standing use.

The redesign reduced on-screen data and clarified hierarchy, prioritising glanceability and simple inputs.

Data entry was moved into context to minimise unnecessary navigation.

Navigation zones were expanded to reflect the ergonomics of one-handed, standing tablet use.

Impact

I prototyped and usability tested the changes before development, reducing uncertainty ahead of build.

Released as an optional setting (“classic” or “new”), the redesign saw over 90% uptake within the first six weeks, enabling a smooth transition for Consultants. Site visit data indicated an improvement in Quality of Service following implementation.

Phase 2

Building on success

As Slimming World moved into a broader digital transformation, I led the experience design of the Consultant toolset, spanning member management, payments and financial administration, group preparation, in-session delivery and reporting, with the weekly group at its core.

My Consultant ecosystem map indicates the scale and scope of my role in the business' digital transformation.
The red circle highlights the subject of this article.

Problem

The member-support screens returned to executive focus, this time within the wider transformation programme and with broader stakeholder involvement. Early in the process, a clear position was stated:

“We're not changing the group process.”

There was appetite to modernise the platform, but the live group model remained central to the business. The expectation was that technology should support it, not redefine it.

A key part of my role was clarifying what that meant in practice. Establishing this boundary early helped frame decisions about what belonged on screen during the session.

Tap to view full map

To anchor the redevelopment, I mapped the two-year lifecycle of a Consultant business to clarify how live delivery connected to preparation, administration and reporting. The map became a reference point across the Consultant ecosystem.

Approach

Working directly with board members and senior stakeholders, I defined the live-session experience in detail — down to information hierarchy and visibility guidelines.

Through co-design workshops and a “buy-your-data” prioritisation exercise with senior Consultants and the company owner, we reviewed each data point and agreed what genuinely needed to surface during the session.

Service safaris with product and engineering built a shared understanding of the live environment. A subsequent Six Thinking Hats session tested assumptions against operational and technical constraints before moving forward.

“…the information for stage one needs to smack you in the face” - Director of the Field

I returned to this comment throughout the process as a way of grounding conversations about clarity and prioritisation.

Outcome

Through structured critique and iteration, I defined:

  • A clearer on-screen information hierarchy
  • Simplified visibility rules
  • A consistent approach to prioritising data during the live session

Decisions were often revisited and refined, with trade-offs discussed in context rather than against fixed rules.

The direction was translated into interactive Figma prototypes and reviewed with board members and stakeholders. Informal hallway testing with Consultants helped refine the approach.

After multiple rounds of iteration, the design was ready to move into simulated group testing.

The very first designs were stripped right back to basics, ensuring any additions had to be discussed and justified in conversation with stakeholders.

Complexity was introduced deliberately, with each addition assessed against how it would perform in the live session.

Figma variables and collections enabled conditional visibility of data points, light and dark mode switching, and metric/imperial unit toggling within a single interactive prototype.

After multiple rounds of iteration and refinement with the business leaders, I was ready to move to a simulated group environment for full usability testing.

“We're not changing the group process.” “We are changing the group process.”

A slight pivot

As the iterative design phase concluded, the company made a methodological shift. The Consultant’s role moved from structured one-to-one support to a more facilitative, member-led format.

The earlier position — “We’re not changing the group process.” — no longer applied.

To understand the implications, I observed the roll-out training and attended groups to see how the new format was working in practice.

It became clear the tool needed to evolve to support a different group dynamic. Rather than discarding the existing work, I adapted.

I introduced an index layer in front of the existing screens — a stripped-back, in-the-moment summary of all members — while preserving immediate access to the deeper data set already defined through research and prioritisation.

I introduced a new index to improve scanability during live sessions, giving Consultants an at-a-glance view of all members in the room.

The structure followed a hub-and-spoke navigation pattern, with the index as the hub and individual member screens as spokes. This enabled flexible, non-linear movement between members as needed, in support of the group conversation.

Advanced prototyping

Having iterated on the index in Figma, I rebuilt the full prototype using Figma Make's AI-assisted code generation to better simulate a live application.

Using prompt-driven logic and lightweight code, I generated dynamic datasets, introduced event-driven interactions and maintained state across member views. This enabled behaviour that would have been difficult to model using standard Figma prototyping alone.

Rebuilding the prototype in Figma Make allowed for dynamic data sets and richer interactivity.

Simulated group testing

To test the design in realistic conditions and build confidence across the organisation, I ran immersive simulated group sessions.

Consultants used the prototype on tablet devices to run live support sessions, while colleagues from design, product, engineering and senior leadership role-played as members.

Testing revealed practical issues that hadn’t emerged in earlier prototype reviews. For example:

  • Heavy use of red on the index screen amplified negative signals when overall group progress was low
  • On-screen keyboard input disrupted conversation flow — replacing free text with selectors maintained engagement
  • Tap targets and interaction timing needed refinement to match live pacing

Following several rounds of iteration, the design was signed off and moved into development, de-risked through early validation and strengthened by direct stakeholder participation.

Rebuilding the prototype in Figma Make enabled realistic data sets and richer interactivity, supporting live testing in realistic conditions.

Impact & reflection

This work formed part of a wider transformation programme and was complex in its own right, shaped by deep organisational investment in the group model and an unexpected shift in how that model was delivered.

Through sustained stakeholder engagement and research validation, I maintained focus on prioritisation and clarity as the scope evolved. Decisions were revisited where needed, but always tested against how they would perform in the live session.

The design entered development signed-off, having been stress-tested under realistic conditions and reviewed with Consultants and senior stakeholders, including the board and Managing Director. It reduced ambiguity ahead of build and de-risked delivery through early validation and structured testing.
